definition.text: the way someone pronounces the words of a language, showing which country or which part of a country they come from

examples.text: He had a strong Irish accent.

definition.text: if the accent is on a particular quality, feeling etc, special importance is given to it

examples.text: accommodation with the accent on comfort

definition.text: the part of a word that you should emphasize when you say it

examples.text: accent on
In the word ‘dinner’ the accent is on the first syllable.

definition.text: a written mark used above or below particular letters in some languages to show how to pronounce that letter
to make something more noticeable so that people will pay attention to it

examples.text: Use make-up to accent your cheekbones and eyes.

definition.text: to emphasize a part of a word in speech
used when giving your opinion about something

examples.text: As far as I’m concerned she can come home whenever she likes.

definition.text: a short performance by an actor, singer etc that someone watches to judge if they are good enough to act in a play, sing in a concert etc

examples.text: audition for
I’ve got an audition for the Bournemouth Symphony Orchestra on Friday.

definition.text: to take part in an audition

meaning.translation: تست بازیگری ، خوانندگی یا غیره دادن

examples.text: audition for
She’s auditioning for Ophelia in ‘Hamlet’.

definition.text: to watch and judge someone’s performance in an audition

meaning.translation: تماشا کردن و داوری کردن تست بازیگری ، خوانندگی و غیره کسی

examples.text: We auditioned more than 200 dancers before deciding on Carole Ann.

definition.text: very bad or unpleasant

examples.text: The weather was awful.
He is a pretty awful driver.
That fridge smells awful.
The last six months have been awful for her.
I’ve stopped believing most of what he says. Isn’t that awful?
I’m sure Suzy is dead but the awful thing is not knowing how it happened.

definition.text: used to emphasize how much or how good, bad etc something is

examples.text: An awful lot of people (= a large number of people ) died in the war.
He made me feel an awful fool.

definition.text: to look or feel ill

meaning.translation: بیمار به نظر رسیدن ، احساس بیماری کردن

examples.text: She’s lost a lot of weight and she looks awful.

definition.text: making you feel great respect or fear
very

examples.text: That kid’s awful cute, with her red curls.

definition.text: making you feel embarrassed so that you are not sure what to do or say

meaning.translation: خجالت آور به نحوی که باعث بشه ندونی چیکار باید کنی یا چی باید بگی

examples.text: I hoped he would stop asking awkward questions .
There was an awkward moment when she didn’t know whether to shake his hand or kiss his cheek.
an awkward silence
A laugh can help people over an awkward situation.
Philip’s remarks put her in an awkward position (= made it difficult for her to know what to do ) .

definition.text: not relaxed or comfortable

meaning.translation: ناراحت (به معنی : راحت و آسوده نبودن)

examples.text: She liked to dance but felt awkward if someone was watching her.
Geoff looked uneasy and awkward.
Make sure that the baby is not sleeping in an awkward position.

definition.text: difficult to do, use, or deal with

examples.text: It’ll be awkward getting cars in and out.
The new financial arrangements were awkward to manage.
A good carpenter can make a cupboard to fit the most awkward space.
She was afraid he was going to ask an awkward question.

definition.text: not convenient

meaning.translation: ناراحت (به معنی : غیر راحت و آسوده)

examples.text: I’m sorry to call at such an awkward time but I won’t keep you a minute.

definition.text: an awkward person is deliberately unhelpful

examples.text: awkward about
The staff wanted to go home and they were getting awkward about a meeting starting so late.
an awkward customer (= person who is difficult and unhelpful )

definition.text: used to show that something happens quickly

meaning.translation: برای نشان دادن اینکه چیزی بک دفعه و به سرعت اتفاق افتاده استفاده می شود

examples.text: He made a run for it and, bam, they shot him in the leg.

definition.text: used to show that something has hit something else

meaning.translation: برای نشان دادن اینکه چیزی به چیز دیگری برخورد کرده استفاده می شود

definition.text: used to make the sound of a gun

meaning.translation: برای ادای صدای تفنگ را در آوردن استفاده می شود

definition.text: to be too difficult for someone to understand

meaning.translation: از فهم کسی خارج بودن (به معنی : فهم آن برای کسی خیلی سخت بودن)

examples.text: The whole problem was quite beyond him.
Why Joan ever married such an idiot in the first place is beyond me.

definition.text: to let air from your stomach come out loudly through your mouth
to send out a large amount of smoke, flames etc, or to come out of something in large amounts

meaning.translation: بیرون دادن/آمدن مقدار زیادی دود ، شعله و غیره

examples.text: a line of chimneys belching out smoke
Flames belched from the wreckage.

definition.text: to treat someone or something as unimportant, for example by not meeting someone or not going to an event

meaning.translation: نادیده گرفتن ، کم توجهی کردن ، اهمیت ندادن

examples.text: Bud got into trouble for blowing off the meeting.

definition.text: to make known something that was secret, especially something involving important or famous people

examples.text: Her book blew the lid off the Reagan years.

definition.text: to kill someone by shooting them in the head
to get rid of anger or energy by doing something

meaning.translation: با انجام کاری عصبانیت یا انرژی خود را خالی کردن

examples.text: I went jogging to blow off some steam.

definition.text: to make you feel very surprised and excited by something

meaning.translation: خیلی متعجب یا هیجان زده کردن

examples.text: Seeing her again really blew my mind.

definition.text: a piece of underwear that a woman wears to support her breasts
new and not yet used

examples.text: a brand-new car
His clothes looked brand-new.

definition.text: very cruel and violent

examples.text: brutal murder/attack/assault
a brutal attack on a defenceless old man
a brutal man

definition.text: not pleasant and not sensitive to people’s feelings

examples.text: He replied with brutal honesty.

definition.text: if something burns up or is burnt up, it is completely destroyed by fire or heat

examples.text: The satellite will burn up as it re-enters the Earth’s atmosphere.
burn something ↔ up
Most of the woodland has now been burnt up.

definition.text: to use a lot of something in a careless way

examples.text: Most household appliances burn up loads of electricity.
He just burns up money!

definition.text: if someone is burning up, they are very hot, usually because they are ill

meaning.translation: داغ بودن (به معنی : دمای بدن بالا داشتن)

examples.text: Feel his forehead – he’s burning up.

definition.text: to make someone very angry

examples.text: The way he treats her really burns me up.

definition.text: to use energy that is stored in your body, by being physically active

meaning.translation: مصرف کردن انرژی ذخیره شدن در بدن

examples.text: As we get older, our body becomes less efficient at burning up calories.

definition.text: a vehicle with no roof that is pulled by a horse and used for carrying heavy things
a large wire basket on wheels that you use in a supermarket
the place on an Internet shopping website where you put things that you wish to buy
a small table with wheels, used for moving and serving food and drinks

definition.lexUnit: put the cart before the horse
definition.text: to do two things in the wrong order
to take something somewhere in a cart, truck etc

examples.text: cart something away
Household waste is carted away by the city’s Sanitation Department.

definition.text: to carry something somewhere, especially something that is heavy or difficult to carry

examples.text: We carted all the furniture upstairs.

definition.text: someone who is staying in a tent or shelter

meaning.translation: کسی که جایی اردو زده (در یک چادر یااستراحتگاه اقامت داره)

definition.text: a vehicle that has cooking equipment and beds in it

meaning.translation: یک وسیله نقلیه که لوازم آشپزی و رخت خواب داخلش داره

definition.text: a special type of tent on wheels that has cooking equipment and beds in it

meaning.translation: یک نوع چادر که زیرش چرخ داره و لوازم آشپزی و رخت خواب داخلش هست

definition.text: a child who is taking part in a camp
someone who seems to be happy with their situation

meaning.translation: کسی که به نظر می رسه از وضعیتش راضی و خوش حاله

definition.text: the part of a song that is repeated after each verse

examples.text: Everyone joined in the chorus.

definition.text: a large group of people who sing together

examples.text: I sing with the university chorus.

definition.text: a piece of music written to be sung by a large group of people

examples.text: a recording of the ‘Hallelujah Chorus’

definition.text: a group of singers, dancers, or actors who act together in a show but do not have the main parts

examples.text: New voices are needed to join the chorus for the annual festival in October.

definition.text: something that a lot of people all say at the same time

examples.text: The minister was greeted with a chorus of boos.
There was a chorus of agreement from the committee.
More politicians have now joined in the chorus of complaints.

definition.text: if people say something in chorus, they say the same thing at the same time

examples.text: ‘Thank you, ’ they said in chorus.

definition.text: if people chorus something, they say it at the same time

examples.text: ‘Hurry up!’ chorused the girls.

definition.text: an alcoholic drink made from a mixture of different drinks
small pieces of fish, prawn s, or lobster served cold with a sauce and eaten as the first part of a meal
a mixture of small pieces of fruit
a mixture of several things which is dangerous, unpleasant, confusing, or exciting

examples.text: cocktail of
a lethal cocktail of painkillers and whisky
The book contains a powerful cocktail of romance, family crises, and big business.

definition.text: when two things happen at the same time, in the same place, or to the same people in a way that seems surprising or unusual

examples.text: ‘I’m going to Appleby tomorrow.’ ‘ What a coincidence ! I’m going there too.’
by coincidence
By coincidence, John and I both ended up at Yale.
sheer/pure coincidence(= completely by chance )
It was sheer coincidence that we were staying in the same hotel.
not a coincidence/more than coincidence(= not chance, but deliberate )
I think it is more than coincidence that all the complaints have come from the same group of people.

definition.text: when two ideas, opinions etc are the same

examples.text: coincidence of
a coincidence of interest between the mining companies and certain politicians

definition.text:
a) to almost do something
b) to be almost as good as someone or something else

examples.text: I tell you, I was so mad I came close to hitting her.
She came so close to the finals she must have been bitterly disappointed to go out now.
It’s not as good as his last movie, but it comes pretty close.

definition.text: an object that is convertible can be folded or arranged in a different way so that it can be used as something else

examples.text: a convertible sofa

definition.text: able to be exchanged for the money of another country

examples.text: a convertible currency

definition.text: a financial document such as an insurance arrangement or a bond that is convertible can be exchanged for money, stock s etc
a car with a soft roof that you can fold back or remove
needing to be dealt with carefully or sensitively in order to avoid problems or failure

examples.text: There’s something I have to speak to you about – it’s a delicate matter.
delicate negotiations

definition.text: easily damaged or broken

examples.text: delicate hand-cut glass
The sun can easily damage a child’s delicate skin .

definition.text: someone who is delicate is hurt easily or easily becomes ill

examples.text: a delicate child

definition.text: a part of the body that is delicate is attractive and graceful

examples.text: Her wrists and ankles were slim and delicate.
her delicate features

definition.text: made skilfully and with attention to the smallest details

examples.text: a plate with a delicate pattern of leaves

definition.text: a taste, smell, or colour that is delicate is pleasant and not strong

examples.text: The wine has a dry delicate flavour.
a delicate pink

definition.text: a liquid or powder used for washing clothes, dishes etc

meaning.translation: مایع یا پودر لباس شویی ، ظرف شویی و غیره

inflections: ( plural discos )
title: disco_noun_1

definition.text: a place or social event at which people dance to recorded popular music

examples.text: the school disco

inflections: ( plural discos )
title: disco_noun_2

definition.text: a type of dance music that was first popular in the 1970s
a machine that dries things, especially clothes
to show something that is usually covered or hidden

examples.text: He lifted his T-shirt to expose a jagged scar across his chest.
expose something to something
Potatoes turn green when exposed to light.

definition.text: to put someone in a situation where they are not protected from something dangerous or unpleasant

examples.text: expose somebody to something
The report revealed that workers had been exposed to high levels of radiation.
expose yourself to ridicule/criticism etc(= say or do something that may make people laugh at you, criticize you etc )

definition.text: to show the truth about someone or something, especially when it is bad

examples.text: The film exposes the utter horror of war.
The report exposes the weaknesses of modern medical practice.
expose somebody as something
The baron was exposed as a liar and a cheat.

definition.text: to make it possible for someone to experience new ideas, ways of life etc

meaning.translation: امکان تجربه چیز جدیدی را فراهم کردن

examples.text: expose somebody to something
Some children are never exposed to classical music.

definition.text: if a man exposes himself, he shows his sexual organs to someone he does not know in a public place, usually because he is mentally ill
to allow light onto a piece of film in a camera in order to take a photograph
to show other people feelings that you usually hide, especially when this is not planned

examples.text: I’m afraid I might expose my real feelings for him.

definition.text: a story in a newspaper or on television that shows the truth about something, especially something dishonest or shocking

examples.text: exposé of
an exposé of corrupt practices by lawyers

definition.text: to continue for a longer period of time, or to make something last longer

meaning.translation: بیشتر ادامه دادن یا ادامه پیدا کردن ، طولانی تر کردن/شدن

examples.text: Management have agreed to extend the deadline.
extend for/into/over etc
Some of our courses extend over two years.
extend something for/by/until something
The government has extended the ban on the import of beef until June.

definition.text: to continue for a particular distance or over a particular area

meaning.translation: بیشتر ادامه دادن یا ادامه پیدا کردن

examples.text: across/over/through etc
The River Nile extends as far south as Lake Victoria.
extend 100 km/30 yards etc (from something)
The shelf extends 20 cms from the bookcase.

definition.text: to make a room, building, road etc bigger or longer

meaning.translation: گسترش دادن ، بزرگتر کردن ، طولانی تر کردن

examples.text: We plan to extend the kitchen by six feet.

definition.text:
a) to affect or include people, things, or places
b) to make something affect more people, situations, areas etc than before

examples.text: extend to/beyond etc
My duties at the school extend beyond just teaching.
The vote was extended to all women aged 21 and over in 1928.
British Coal is planning to extend its operations in Wales.
extend something to somebody/something
We can extend our insurance cover to travel abroad.

definition.text: to officially offer someone help, sympathy, thanks etc

examples.text: extend something to somebody(= allow them to borrow more money )
We’d like to extend a warm welcome to our French visitors.
I’d like to extend my thanks to all the catering staff.
The Coroner extended his sympathy to the victim’s family.
The Headteacher has extended an invitation to the prime minister to visit the school.
The banks have decided to extend credit to the company (= allow them to borrow more money ) .

definition.text: to stretch out a hand or leg

examples.text: George extended his hand (= offered to shake hands ) .

definition.text: to increase the number of points, games etc by which one person or team is ahead of other competitors

examples.text: Manchester United extended their lead at the top of the table to 10 points.

definition.text: if a table or ladder extends, it can be made longer
a liquid that you put in water when washing clothes in order to make them feel softer
something that you do for someone in order to help them or be kind to them

examples.text: Could you do me a favour and tell Kelly I can’t make it?
He hired John as a favour to his father.
Paul, can I ask you a favor ?
I owed him a favour so I couldn’t say no.
She helps me out when I have too much to do, and I return the favour when I can.
Do yourself a favour and make sure you get some time to yourself.

definition.text: support, approval, or agreement for something such as a plan, idea, or system

meaning.translation: حمایت ، تأیید یا موافقت با چیزی

examples.text: in favour of something
Senior ministers spoke in favour of the proposal.
I talked to Susie about it, and she’s all in favor (= completely approves ) of going.
find/gain/win favour
The idea may find favor with older people.
in somebody/something’s favour
The vote was 60–59 in the government’s favor.
In Sweden and other countries, nuclear power has lost favor .
look on/view/regard something with favour(= support something, and want to help it succeed )
Employers are more likely to look with favour on experienced candidates.
All in favour (= used when asking people to vote on something by raising a hand ) ?
vote/decide in favour of something(= vote or decide to support something )
288 members voted in favor of the ban.
find/rule in favour of somebody(= make a legal decision that supports someone )

definition.text: when someone or something is liked or approved of by people, or not liked or approved of

examples.text: be in favour (with somebody)
The island is very much in favour as a holiday destination.
be out of favour (with somebody)
The stock is currently out of favor with investors.
find/gain/win favour
Radcliffe’s books began to find favour with the reading public.
come/be back in favour(= become popular again )
Fountain pens have come back in favour.
fall/go out of favour(= stop being approved of )
Grammar-based teaching methods went out of favour in the 60s and 70s.

definition.text: if something is in someone’s favour, it gives them an advantage over someone else

examples.text: Conditions on court are very much in Williams’ favour.
The new rules should actually work in your favor.
Duncan had his height and weight in his favour during the fight.
the odds are (stacked) in somebody’s favour(= someone has a big advantage )

definition.lexUnit: do something in favour of something
definition.text: if you decide not to use one thing in favour of another, you choose the other one because you think it is better

examples.text: Plans for a tunnel were rejected in favour of a bridge.

definition.text: to do something that makes someone or something look worse than they are, or that does not help at all

meaning.translation: وضعیت کسی یا چیزی را بدتر کردن یا کمکی به آن نکردن

examples.text: Low interest rates don’t do savers any favours.

definition.text: support that is given to one person or group and not to others, in a way that does not seem fair

examples.text: Teachers should not show favour to any pupil.

definition.text: used when you are annoyed because someone has asked a silly question or done something to upset people

examples.text: Do us a favour, Mike, and shut up!
‘Did you like it?’ ‘Do me a favour!’

definition.text: a party favor
when you allow someone to have sex with you

examples.text: She shared her sexual favors with many men.

definition.text: to prefer someone or something to other things or people, especially when there are several to choose from

examples.text: Both countries seem to favour the agreement.
loose clothing of the type favoured in Arab countries
favour somebody/something over somebody/something
Florida voters favored Bush over Gore by a very small margin.

definition.text: to treat someone much better than someone else, in a way that is not fair

examples.text: a tax cut that favours rich people
favour somebody over somebody
a judicial system that favours men over women

definition.text: to provide suitable conditions for something to happen

examples.text: The current economy does not favour the development of small businesses.

definition.text: to be expected to win or be the one that is successful

examples.text: Silva is favoured to win a medal in the marathon.

definition.text: to look like one of your parents or grandparents

inflections: ( flopped, flopping )
title: flop_verb_1

definition.text: to sit or lie down in a relaxed way, by letting all your weight fall heavily onto a chair etc

meaning.translation: خود را ولو کردن (روی صندلی ، مبل ، تخت و غیره)

examples.text: He flopped down onto the bed.
I got home and flopped in front of the TV.

inflections: ( flopped, flopping )
title: flop_verb_2

definition.text: to hang or fall loosely, in an uncontrolled way

examples.text: His head flopped back pathetically.

inflections: ( flopped, flopping )
title: flop_verb_3

definition.text: if something such as a product, play, or idea flops, it is not successful because people do not like it
a film, play, product etc that is not successful

meaning.translation: یک فیلم ، نمایش ، محصول یا غیره که موفق نبوده

examples.text: disastrous/spectacular etc flop
The film was a complete flop.

definition.text: the movement or noise that something makes when it falls heavily

examples.text: He fell with a flop into the water.

definition.text: very light and soft to touch

examples.text: a fluffy little kitten
fluffy towels

definition.text: food that is fluffy is made soft and light by mixing it quickly so that a lot of air is mixed into it

meaning.translation: نرم و سبک و پف کرده

examples.text: Cream the butter and sugar until the mixture is light and fluffy.

definition.text: fluffy clouds look light and soft
not serious or important

examples.text: Her new book is a fluffy romantic fantasy.

definition.text: very unusual and strange, and sometimes frightening

examples.text: freakish weather

definition.text: if a sound or picture is fuzzy, it is unclear

examples.text: Some of the photos were so fuzzy it was hard to tell who was who.

definition.text: unclear or confused

examples.text: There’s a fuzzy line between parents’ and schools’ responsibilities.

definition.text: covered with soft short hair or fur

examples.text: I stroked the kitten’s fuzzy back.

definition.text: fuzzy hair is very curly and sticks straight up
if people gang up on someone, they join together to attack, criticize, or oppose them, especially in a way that seems unfair

examples.text: Schoolchildren are quick to gang up on anyone who looks or behaves differently.

definition.text: kind and careful in the way you behave or do things, so that you do not hurt or damage anyone or anything

meaning.translation: مهربان ، مراقب و ملایم در رفتار یا انجام کارها

examples.text: Arthur was a very gentle, caring person.
gentle voice/smile/touch
‘Where does it hurt?’ she asked in a gentle voice.
gentle with
Be gentle with the baby.

definition.text: not extreme, strong, or violent

examples.text: gentle exercise/walk/stroll etc
a program of regular gentle exercise
the gentle pressure of Jill’s hand
After a little gentle persuasion, she agreed to go back to her family.
Melt the butter over a gentle heat  (= low heat ).

definition.text: a gentle wind or rain is soft and light

examples.text: a gentle breeze

definition.text: a gentle hill or slope is not steep or sharp

examples.text: the gentle slopes of Mt Pelée

definition.text: the attractive and exciting quality of being connected with wealth and success

meaning.translation: جذابیت به دلیل ثروتمند بودن یا موفق بودن

examples.text: glamour of
Forget all you read about the glamour of television.

definition.text: a style or attractiveness that suggests wealth

meaning.translation: استایل یا جذابیتی که ثروتمند بودن را القاء می کند

examples.text: Designer clothes are not a passport to instant glamour.

definition.text: a performer who is more noticeable for their attractiveness than for their skill or ability

a) to stop working properly
b) to make a mistake during a process so that you do not get the right result
c) to do something that makes a plan, relationship etc fail

meaning.translation: آ) دچار مشکل شدن ب) اشتباه کردن ج) اشتباه کردن

examples.text: Something’s gone wrong with my watch.
Follow these instructions and you can’t go wrong (= you are sure to succeed ) .
Thinking back on the marriage, I just don’t know where we went wrong.

definition.text: to feel extremely sad, especially because someone you love has died

examples.text: grieve over/for
He died, and every day since then I have grieved for him.
People need time to grieve after the death of a loved one.
She grieved the loss of her only son.

definition.text: if something grieves you, it makes you feel very unhappy

meaning.translation: خیلی ناراحت کردن ، ماتم زده کردن

examples.text: My aunt, it grieves me to say, gets things confused.

definition.text: a situation in which someone refuses to eat for a long time in order to protest about something

examples.text: A total of 300 students occupied the building and over 50 went on hunger strike.

definition.text: not suitable or right for a particular purpose or in a particular situation

examples.text: wholly/totally/completely etc inappropriate
His comments were wholly inappropriate on such a solemn occasion.
it is inappropriate (for somebody) to do something
It would be inappropriate for me to comment until we know more of the facts.
inappropriate for
an inappropriate gift for a child
inappropriate to
marketing techniques that are totally inappropriate to education
inappropriate behaviour/response/language etc

definition.text: to fill something with air or gas so it becomes larger, or to become filled with air or gas

examples.text: It took us half an hour to inflate the dinghy.

definition.text: to make something seem more important or impressive than it really is

examples.text: The success further inflated his self-confidence.
be grossly/vastly/hugely inflated
The numbers of people involved have been grossly inflated by the media.

definition.text: to increase in price, or to make something increase in price

examples.text: Hotels often inflate prices at particular times of the year.
Costs were inflating.

definition.text: the people or language of a particular country or place

examples.text: Are the British unfriendly?
learning to speak Turkish
She’s Swedish.

definition.text: of a particular place

examples.text: Spanish food (= from Spain )

definition.text: typical of or like a particular type of person

examples.text: foolish behaviour (= typical of a fool )
Don’t be so childish! (= do not behave like a child )
snobbish

definition.text: the ending of some adjectives that show disapproval

examples.text: selfish

definition.text: rather

examples.text: youngish (= not very young, but not old either )
tallish
reddish hair

definition.text: approximately

examples.text: We’ll expect you around eightish (= at about eight o'clock ) .
He’s fortyish (= about 40 years old ) .

inflections: ( plural laundries )
title: laundry_noun_1

definition.text: clothes, sheets etc that need to be washed or have just been washed

meaning.translation: رخت و لباسی که نیازه شسته بشن یا تازه شسته شدن

examples.text: She did the laundry  (= washed the clothes etc ) and hung it out to dry.
Ben was folding laundry.
clean/dirty laundry
a pile of dirty laundry

inflections: ( plural laundries )
title: laundry_noun_2

definition.text: a place or business where clothes etc are washed and ironed

a) to succeed in getting somewhere in time for something or when this is difficult
b) to be successful at something, for example in your job
c) to be able to go to an event, meeting etc that has been arranged
d) to continue to live after you have been seriously ill or badly injured
e) to manage to deal with a difficult experience
f) used to say or ask what time it is according to your own or someone else’s watch

meaning.translation: آ) به موقع رسیدن به جایی ب) موفق بودن د) زنده ماندن

examples.text: If we run, we should make it.
make it to
With blood pouring from his leg, he made it to a nearby house.
He came to the US and not only made it but made it big (= was extremely successful ) .
So far, relatively few women have made it to the top in the business world.
make it as
He was told he had no talent and would never make it as a professional singer.
make it to
England look less likely to make it to the finals.
make it to manager/director etc
How did anyone so stupid make it to manager?
I’m really sorry, but I won’t be able to make it on Sunday after all.
Nice to see you. I’m glad you could make it.
Frank was very ill, and the doctors didn’t think he’d make it.
make it through
I couldn’t have made it through those times without the support of my boyfriend.
What time do you make it?
I make it ten past three.

definition.text:
a) to stop holding something or someone
b) to accept that you cannot change something and stop thinking or worrying about it

meaning.translation: آ) رها کردن ب) بیخیال چیزی شدن

examples.text: Let go! You’re hurting me.
let go of
The guard let go of the lead, and the dog lunged forward.
Sometimes you just have to learn to let go.

definition.text:
a)the situation that exists at a particular time
b)the appearance of an area of land, for example the way it slopes

examples.text: Get the lay of the land before you make any decisions.

definition.text: the appearance of something and where each part of it is

examples.text: Mr. Lowe will give you the lay of the camp and tell you what we’re going to be doing.

definition.text: to be a good, quick etc person to have sex with
a poem or song

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_1

definition.text: to put someone or something down carefully into a flat position

examples.text: He laid his hand on my shoulder.

Lay the material flat on the table.

definition.text: to put or fasten bricks, a carpet etc in the correct place, especially on the ground or floor

examples.text: The carpet was laid last week.
The project involved laying an oil pipeline across the desert.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_3

definition.text: if a bird, insect etc lays eggs, it produces them from its body

examples.text: The flies lay their eggs on decaying meat.
A cuckoo is able to lay in a range of different nests.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_4

definition.text: to put the cloth, plates, knives, forks etc on a table, ready for a meal

examples.text: John was laying the table .
As she spoke, she was laying him a place at the table.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_5

definition.text: to provide the conditions that will make it possible for something to happen or be successful

examples.text: lay the foundations/groundwork/base for
Mandela helped lay the foundations for a new democratic South Africa.
It was an invention which laid the foundations of modern radio technology.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_6

definition.text: to make a statement, give information etc in an official or public way

examples.text: Several proposals have been laid before the committee.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_7

definition.text: to emphasize something because you believe it is very important

examples.text: a political philosophy that lays great stress on individual responsibility

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_8

definition.text: to touch someone with the intention of hurting them

examples.text: I swear I didn’t lay a finger on him.

definition.text:
a)to show what something is really like, or stop hiding facts, feelings etc
b)to remove the thing that is covering or hiding something else

examples.text: Every aspect of their private life has been laid bare.
When the tide goes out, vast stretches of sand are laid bare.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_10

definition.text: to do something that makes it possible for other people to blame you, criticize you etc

examples.text: lay yourself open to something
By doing that, he laid himself open to ridicule.
Not to have taken action would have laid the department open to charges of negligence.

definition.text: to destroy or damage something, especially in a war

examples.text: The island was laid waste and abandoned.
an attack which laid waste to hundreds of villages

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_12

definition.text: to carefully prepare all the details of something

examples.text: We are laying plans now in order to be successful in the future.
the best-laid plans(= plans that have been made carefully )
Bad weather can upset even the best-laid travel plans.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_13

definition.text: to say that something belongs to you or say that you deserve something

examples.text: The town can lay claim to having the oldest theatre in Britain.
No one has laid claim to the property.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_14

definition.text:
a)if a group of people lay siege to a place, they try to get control by surrounding it
b)to do everything you can to get someone to talk to you or notice you

examples.text: The armies laid siege to Vienna in 1529.
In June 1176, King Richard laid siege to Limoges.
A group of young men were always at the stage door, trying to lay siege to the girls.
Then he set to work laying siege to her with letters.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )

examples.text: All he wants to do is go out and get laid .

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )
title: lay_verb_18

definition.text:
a)to state something, especially a threat, demand, or criticism, in a very clear way
b)to risk losing your life, your job etc, especially in order to help someone

examples.text: Lay it on the line and tell them what’s really been happening.
I’ve laid myself on the line for him once already.

title: lay_verb_19

definition.lexUnit: lay something at the door of somebody/something
definition.text: to blame something or someone for something

examples.text: The continued divisions within the party cannot be laid entirely at his door.
Many illnesses are being laid at the door of stress.

title: lay_verb_20

a)if an illness lays someone low, they are unable to do their normal activities for a period of time
b)to make someone fall down, or injure them seriously

examples.text: be laid low with something

inflections: ( past tense and past participle laid / leɪd / )

examples.text: She was laid to rest beside her husband.

definition.text: to finally stop being worried or upset by something from the past

a) not trained or not knowing much about a particular profession or subject

examples.text: lay witnesses
a lay preacher

definition.text: a skilful or careful movement that you make, for example in order to avoid something or go through a narrow space

examples.text: A careful driver will often stop talking before carrying out a complex manoeuvre.

definition.text: a skilful or carefully planned action intended to gain an advantage for yourself

examples.text: They tried by diplomatic maneuvers to obtain an agreement.

definition.text: military activities, such as pretending to fight a battle, which are done as practice or training

examples.text: Large-scale military manoeuvres are being carried out near the border.
on manoeuvres
troops on night manoeuvres

definition.text: the possibility of changing your plans or decisions in order to achieve what you want

examples.text: As I see it, Lisa, you don’t really have a great deal of room for manoeuvre.

definition.text: to move or turn skilfully or to move or turn something skilfully, especially something large and heavy

examples.text: She managed to manoeuvre expertly into the parking space.
manoeuvre yourself into/out of something
Josh manoeuvred himself out of bed and hobbled to the door.
We manoeuvred the TV in front of the sofa.

definition.text: to use cleverly planned and often dishonest methods to get the result that you want

examples.text: manoeuvre somebody into/out of something
It was a well-organized plan to maneuver company president John Woolford out of office.
Businesses manoeuvred to have their industry organized to their own advantage.

definition.text: a very soft light white or pink sweet, made of sugar and egg white
the average amount, figure, or value

examples.text: The mean of 7,9 and 14 is 10.

definition.lexUnit: the/a mean between something and something
definition.text: a method of doing something which is between two very different methods, and better than either of them

examples.text: It’s a case of finding the mean between firmness and compassion.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_1

f2n.heading: Register
f2n.explanation: In written English, people often prefer to say that something indicates something is the case, rather than using mean :
examples: The light indicates that fuel supplies are low.

definition.text: to have or represent a particular meaning

examples.text: What does ‘patronizing’ mean ?
The red light means ‘Stop’.
The report fails to define what is meant by the term ‘key issues’.
mean (that)
This light means you’re running low on fuel.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_2

definition.text: to intend a particular meaning when you say something

examples.text: mean (that)
I meant we’d have to leave early – that’s all.
It’s pretty obvious what she means .
(do) you mean(= used to check you have understood what someone intended to say )
Do you mean you’ve changed or Chris has changed?
do/if you know/see what I mean?(= used to check that someone understands you )
I want to buy her something really special, if you know what I mean.
We’re still married but living apart in the same house, if you see what I mean.
Oh yeah! I see what you mean (= I understand what you are trying to say ) .
What I mean is, I don’t feel alone anymore (= used to explain more about what you have said ) .
‘I didn’t really like him.’ ' I know what you mean, I didn’t get on with him either (= used to say you understand and have had the same experience ) .
‘In three hours’ time, I’ll be a free man.‘ ’ How do you mean (= used to ask someone to explain what they have just said ) ?'

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_3

definition.text: to intend to do something or intend that someone else should do something

examples.text: mean to do something
I’ve been meaning to ask you if you want to come for a meal next week.
I didn’t mean to upset you.
mean somebody/something to do something
I didn’t mean this to happen at all.
I never meant you to find out.
mean for somebody to do something
I didn’t mean for her to get hurt.
I’m sure she didn’t mean it (= she did not intend to upset or hurt someone ) .
mean no harm/offence/disrespect(= not intend to harm, offend etc someone )
I’m sure he didn’t mean any harm.
He may sound a bit rude at times, but he means well (= intends to be helpful or kind, even if it does not seem like that ) .
I wasn’t criticizing you, I really meant it for the best (= wanted to be helpful, although my actions had the wrong effect ) .

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_4

definition.text: to have a particular result or involve something

examples.text: The merger will mean the closure of the company’s Sydney office.
Don’t let him see you. It will only mean trouble.
mean (that)
The high cost of housing means that many young people can’t afford to buy a house.
mean doing something
My new job will mean travelling all over the world.
Dieting also means being careful about which foods you buy.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_5

definition.text: if a name, word etc means something to you, you are familiar with it or you understand it

meaning.translation: آشنا بودن با چیزی ، فهمیدن چیزی

examples.text: He said his name was ‘Randall’ but it meant nothing to me (= I was not familiar with it ).
Does the name Bryce mean anything to you?
You need to use analogies which will mean something to the reader.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_6

definition.text: to be serious about what you are saying or writing

meaning.translation: جدی بودن در مورد چیزی که داری میگی یا می نویسی

examples.text: With children, if you say ‘no’, you have to mean it .
I meant what I said earlier.
You don’t really mean that, do you?

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_7

definition.text: used for saying how important someone or something is to you

examples.text: mean something to somebody
I know how much your work means to you.
The medal meant a lot to him.
mean the world to somebody/mean everything to somebody(= be very important to someone )
He meant the world to her.
Time meant nothing (= it was not important ) to me while I was travelling.
Of course the relationship meant something to me.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_8

definition.text: to be a sign that something is true or will happen

meaning.translation: نشانه چیزی بودن ، معنی فلان چیز رو دادن

examples.text: mean (that)
Finding a lump does not necessarily mean you have cancer.
Clear skies mean that it will be a cold night.
Just because he’s been in prison, it doesn’t mean that he’s violent.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_9

definition.text:
a)used when you do not understand what someone is trying to say
b)used when you are very surprised or annoyed by what someone has just said
c)used when you are very annoyed by what someone has just done

examples.text: ‘You’ll be careful won’t you?’ ‘What do you mean?’

What do you mean by that?
What do you mean by calling me at this time of night?

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_10

definition.text: used to say that a particular person or thing is the one that you are talking about, pointing to etc

examples.text: ‘Hey you!’ ‘Do you mean me?’
I meant the pink dress, not the red one.

inflections: ( past tense and past participle meant / ment / )
title: mean_verb_11

definition.text:
a)used when explaining or giving an example of something, or when pausing to think about what you are going to say next
b)used to quickly correct something you have just said

examples.text: You’re more of an expert than me. I mean, you’ve got all that experience.

examples.text: See what I mean? Every time she calls me up she wants me to do something for her.

examples.text: ‘We might not have enough money.’ ‘That’s what I mean, so we’d better find out the price first.’

examples.text: Of course she wants to see the children – I mean to say, it’s only natural isn’t it?

 b) to be determined to do something

examples.text: The border is guarded by troops who mean business.

title: mean_adjective_1

definition.text: cruel or not kind

examples.text: That was a mean thing to do.

mean to

title: mean_adjective_2

mean with

examples.text: They sold 1 million cards in the first year of business – no mean feat, given the problems many businesses are facing.

examples.text: Kinnock is no mean performer on the rugby field.

examples.text: The study involved 60 patients with a mean age of 58.2 years.

tidy and carefully arranged

examples.text: neat handwriting

definition.text: someone who is neat likes to keep things tidy

examples.text: I’ve always been quite neat.

definition.text: very good, pleasant, or enjoyable

meaning.translation: خیلی خوب ، مطبوع یا لذت بخش

examples.text: That’s a really neat idea.

examples.text: her small, neat features

examples.text: In the end we found a very neat solution to the problem.
a neat summary of the main issues

definition.text: a neat alcoholic drink has no ice or water or any other liquid added

examples.text: I can’t drink brandy neat.
drinking neat whisky

definition.text: to eat small amounts of food by taking very small bites

examples.text: He nibbled the biscuit cautiously.
nibble at
There’s a fish nibbling at my bait.
nibble on
He nibbled on a piece of raw carrot.

definition.text: to gently bite someone in a loving way

examples.text: He began to nibble her ear affectionately.

definition.text: a small bite of something

examples.text: nibble of
She took a nibble of her cookie.

definition.text: small things to eat, like crisps and peanuts, especially at a party
a small amount of interest in something

examples.text: We’ve had the house on the market for a month and not even had a nibble yet.

definition.text: the greatest point of sexual pleasure

examples.text: women who have never had an orgasm

definition.text: used to say that someone should do something because it is the best or most sensible thing to do

examples.text: You really ought to quit smoking.
The company ought to be making changes in its marketing strategy.
What sort of crimes ought the police to concentrate on?
You were out enjoying yourself when you ought to have been studying.

definition.text: used to make a suggestion about something you think is a good idea, especially in a social situation

examples.text: We ought to get together some time soon.
You ought to meet him; he’s really nice.
We ought to get her some flowers for her birthday.
I ought to call Brian.

definition.text: used to say that someone should do something or something should happen, because it is morally right or fair

examples.text: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
The courts ought to treat black and white defendants in exactly the same way.
Many people felt that America ought not to take part in the war.

definition.text: used to say that you think something will probably happen, is probably true etc

examples.text: He left two hours ago, so he ought to be there by now.
They ought to win – they’ve trained hard enough.
That ought to be enough potatoes for eight people.
New technology ought to make this easier.

title: rat_verb_2

definition.text: to not do what you had promised to do

meaning.translation: خلف وعده کردن ، زیر قول خود زدن

examples.text: rat on
He accused the government of ratting on its promises to the disabled.

definition.text: the distance that you can stretch out your arm to touch something

examples.text: out of/beyond (somebody’s) reach
Keep chemicals out of the reach of children.
within reach (of somebody)
Keep a glass of water within reach.

definition.text: close to a place

examples.text: The beach is within easy reach of the hotel.

definition.text: the limit of someone’s power or ability to do something

examples.text: beyond the reach of somebody
He lives in Paraguay, well beyond the reach of the British authorities.

definition.text:
a)the parts of a place that are furthest from the centre
b)the straight part of a river between two bends

examples.text: the further/outer reaches of something
the further reaches of the jungle
the upper reaches of the Nile

definition.text: the high or low levels of an organization or system

examples.text: They lingered in the lower reaches of the Football League.

f2n.heading: Register
f2n.explanation: In everyday English, people often use get to rather than reach :
examples: The kids have got to the age where they can care for themselves.

definition.text: if someone or something reaches a particular point in their development or in a process or competition, they get to that point

examples.text: Chelsea could reach the final of the European Cup.
reach the point/level/stage etc
I had reached the point where I was earning a good salary.
The kids have reached the age when they can care for themselves.

definition.text: if something reaches a particular rate, amount etc, it increases until it is at that rate or amount

examples.text: By 2008, that figure is expected to reach 7 million.
wind speeds reaching up to 180 mph
Prices rose steadily to reach record levels .

definition.text: to agree on something or decide something after a lot of discussion or thought

examples.text: reach a decision/agreement etc
The theatre has reached an agreement with striking actors.
It took the jury three days to reach a verdict .
The talks will continue until a conclusion is reached .

definition.text: to achieve what you wanted to achieve

meaning.translation: رسیدن به چیزی ، بدست آوردن چیزی

examples.text: We hope to reach our £1 million target by the autumn.

definition.text:
a) to move your arm in order to touch or lift something with your hand
b) to touch something by stretching out your arm
c) to get something from a high place by stretching up your arm

examples.text: She reached into her bag and produced a business card.
He reached down to help her to her feet.
reach for
Kelly reached for his gun.
Luisa reached out her hand to stroke the cat.
It’s no good – I can’t reach.
She’s too small to reach the table.
reach something down
She fell while reaching down a vase from the top shelf.

definition.text: to be big enough, long enough etc to get to a particular point

examples.text: The phone lead isn’t long enough to reach the bedroom.
a skirt that reaches halfway down her legs
reach as far as something/reach down to something
Her hair reaches down to her waist.

f2n.heading: Register
f2n.explanation: In everyday English, people often use get to rather than reach :
examples: We got to the airport just in time.
You can get to the pyramids by public transport.

definition.text: to arrive at a place

examples.text: We reached London late at night.
The pyramids can be reached by public transport.

definition.text: if you reach someone, you succeed in speaking to them on the telephone

examples.text: I can probably reach him on his mobile.

definition.text: if a message, television programme etc reaches a lot of people, they hear it or see it

examples.text: Cable TV reaches a huge audience .

definition.text: if information reaches you, you hear about it

examples.text: The news reached us in Lahore.

definition.text: to succeed in making someone understand or accept what you tell them

examples.text: I just can’t seem to reach Ed anymore.

definition.text: to aim for something that is very difficult to achieve
to tear or pull something to pieces

examples.text: He was ripped apart by savage beasts in the forest.

definition.text: to hit someone or something with a vehicle, and drive over them

examples.text: He was run over and killed by a bus.
She got run over outside the school.

definition.text: to think about something

examples.text: Mark’s mind raced, running over all the possibilities.

definition.text: to explain or practise something quickly

examples.text: I’ll just run over the main points again.

definition.text: to continue happening for longer than planned

examples.text: The meeting ran over.
The talks have run over the 15 November deadline.

definition.text: if a container runs over, there is so much liquid inside that some flows out

inflections: ( plural scrunchies )
title: scrunchy

definition.text: a small circular piece of rubber covered loosely with cloth, which is used for holding hair together in a ponytail
to cut off hair very close to the skin, especially from the face, using a razor

examples.text: He hadn’t shaved for days.
Brian had cut himself shaving .
shave your head/legs/armpits etc
She shaved her legs and underarms.

definition.text: to remove very thin pieces from the surface of something

examples.text: Shave thin strips of cheese over the pasta.

definition.text: if a man has a shave, he cuts off the hair on his face close to his skin using a razor

examples.text: He looked as if he needed a shave.
have a shave
I’ll just have a shave before we go.

definition.text: a) when the hair on someone’s face is cut very close to the skin b) a situation in which you only just avoid an accident or something bad

examples.text: Phew, that was a close shave.

definition.text: the part of a piece of clothing that covers all or part of your arm

examples.text: a dress with long sleeves
long-sleeved/short-sleeved etc
a short-sleeved shirt

definition.text: to have a secret plan or idea that you are going to use later

examples.text: Don’t worry. He still has a few tricks up his sleeve.

definition.text: a stiff paper cover that a record is stored in
to settle into a warm comfortable position

examples.text: snuggle up/down/against etc
She snuggled up in Lea's lap to listen to the story.

definition.text: a small animal with a long furry tail that climbs trees and eats nuts
the mass of bubbles formed on the top of water with soap in it
extremely or to the greatest possible degree

meaning.translation: خیلی زیاد یا در بیشترین حد ممکن

examples.text: a supremely talented player

definition.text: to think carefully about the possible results of something

examples.text: The policy has not been thought through properly.
It’s my fault. I didn’t think it through.
I need time to think things through.
think through what/how
People need time to think through what the changes will mean for them.

definition.text: a flat square piece of baked clay or other material, used for covering walls, floors etc

examples.text: a flat square piece of baked clay or other material, used for covering walls, floors etc

definition.text: a thin curved piece of baked clay used for covering roofs
out drinking, dancing etc for enjoyment until late at night
to cover a roof, floor etc with tiles

meaning.translation: کاشی کاری کردن ، موزاییک کاری کردن

definition.text: someone who often behaves in a violent way

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_1

definition.text: difficult to do or deal with

examples.text: It was a tough race.
She’s had a tough life.
The company admitted that it had been a tough year.
Tough decisions will have to be made.
The reporters were asking a lot of tough questions .
have a tough time (of it)(= face a lot of difficult problems )
The family has had a tough time of it these last few months.
it’s tough doing something
It’s tough being married to a cop.
be tough on somebody(= cause problems for someone or make their life difficult )
Having to stay indoors all day is tough on a kid.
It was a tough call (= a difficult decision ), but we had to cancel the game because of the weather.
I find his books pretty tough going (= difficult to read ) .
Gage predicted the president’s proposal would be a tough sell (= something that is difficult to persuade someone about ) before Congress. American English
when the going gets tough (the tough get going)(= used to say that when a situation becomes difficult, strong people take the necessary action to deal with it )

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_2

definition.text: physically or emotionally strong and able to deal with difficult situations

examples.text: The men who work on the oil rigs are a tough bunch.
tough cookie/customer(= someone who is very determined to do what they want and not what other people want )
as tough as nails/as tough as old boots(= very tough )
He’s as tough as nails – a good man to have on the team.

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_3

definition.text: not easily broken or made weaker

examples.text: tough, durable plastic
a very tough, hard-wearing cloth

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_4

definition.text: very strict or firm

examples.text: tough on/with
My mother was very tough on my sister.
It’s time to get tough with drunk drivers.
The EU is taking a tough line with the UK over this issue.

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_5

definition.text: a tough part of a town has a lot of crime or violence

examples.text: tough neighborhood/area/part of town etc
a tough area of Chicago

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_6

definition.text: used when you do not have any sympathy with someone

examples.text: ‘I’m getting wet.’ ‘Tough! You should’ve brought your umbrella.’
She didn’t tell us she was coming, so if this screws up her plans that’s just tough.

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_7

definition.text:
a)used when you do not have any sympathy for someone’s problems
b)used when you feel sympathy about something bad that has happened to someone

examples.text: Well, that’s just their tough luck! It was their mistake.
You didn’t get the job? Oh, tough luck!

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_8

definition.text: used when you do not have any sympathy for someone’s problems

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_9

definition.text: likely to behave violently and having no gentle qualities

examples.text: one of football’s most notorious tough guys
tough young thugs looking for trouble

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_10

definition.text: difficult to cut or eat

examples.text: The meat was tough and hard to chew.
the tough outer leaves of the cabbage

inflections: ( comparative tougher, superlative toughest )
title: tough_adjective_11

definition.text: a way of helping someone to change their behaviour by treating them in a kind but strict way
in a way that shows you are very determined

examples.text: Washington played tough in the second half of the game.
You’re talking tough now but you wait until you get into the interview.

definition.text: a person, team etc that is weaker than the others, is always expected to be unsuccessful, and that is often treated badly

examples.text: Crowds often feel sympathy for the underdog .

definition.text: a small thin furry animal that kills and eats rats and birds
an injury to your body that is made by a weapon such as a knife or a bullet

examples.text: A nurse cleaned and bandaged the wound.
It took several months for his wounds to heal .
suffer/receive a wound
Several of the victims suffered severe stab wounds.
head/leg etc wound
He was treated in hospital for head wounds.
stab/knife/gunshot wound
He died of gunshot wounds.
The doctor said it was only a flesh wound (= one that does not cut the skin very deeply ) .
a gaping wound (= one that is wide and open ) on his thigh

definition.text: a feeling of emotional or mental pain that you get when someone says or does something unpleasant to you

examples.text: It will take much longer for the mental wounds to heal .

definition.text: to remind someone of unpleasant things that happened in the past
to injure someone with a knife, gun etc

examples.text: Gunmen killed two people and wounded six others in an attack today.
be badly/seriously/critically etc wounded
Five people were killed and many others were seriously wounded in the attack.
be mortally/fatally wounded(= be wounded so badly that you die )

definition.text: to make someone feel unhappy or upset

examples.text: I was deeply wounded by his comments.
He made some very wounding remarks.

definition.text: used to show you are surprised by what someone has told you – also often used when you are not at all surprised by what someone has told you
